node.title: What you need to know about summer sleep in Alaska - AKRDY
node.content:
Living in Alaska has its perks, especially in the summer. Unfortunately, one of those summer perks also comes with a summer drawback, getting a good night’s sleep in the land of the Midnight Sun.

It’s true, most of Alaska receives almost 20 hours of daylight in the summer. The summer sunlight begins to ramp up in May and starts to taper off by the end of August. The far north of Alaska receives almost two consecutive months of total daylight in the summer while other parts of Alaska, for instance, along the Kenai Peninsula, see closer to 19 hours of daylight. Even though most of Alaska, see the sunset in the summer, Alaska doesn’t see full dark. Instead, Alaska receives what is known as civil twilight (or just twilight) for about two to three hours for most of the summer months.

Near constant daylight sounds like a great idea, until you check your phone or your watch and realize it’s 0200 and the sun has started to set. No wonder you’re tired!

Summer sleep in Alaska may not be an easy adjustment for even the most seasoned military family, so we’ve compiled some helpful tips and supplies you may need to make the transition easier.

Make time for winding down and relaxing

It’s tempting to give in to the extra daylight and fish a little bit longer or plant one more row in the garden, but it won’t help you fall asleep. Your body and mind need time to unwind and prepare for sleep. There are several activities you can do to quiet your mind and your body.

  • Read a book
  • Listen to soothing music.
  • Meditate
  • Take a warm bath or shower
  • Write in a journal or write out tomorrow’s to-do list.

One of the best things you can do to relax is to turn off your devices 30 to 60 minutes before bedtime. If you typically use a tablet or smartphone for reading or listening to music, make sure the blue light filter is on.

Create the proper sleep environment

To go to sleep, your body and mind must agree that it’s time to sleep. The right sleep environment can make all the difference in how your body relaxes. The more relaxed your body is, the easier it may be to fall asleep.

Simple things like turning down the thermostat or having an aromatherapy diffuser can help set the scene for good sleep.

Your room should be a quiet, comfortable space for sleeping. Some people find a sleep machine, white noise machine, or other sounds such as crickets, owls, frogs, even thunderstorms, (all things you might hear at night in the lower 48), help lull you to sleep as you adjust to Alaska’s unique summer.

Investing in darkening curtains or darkening blinds is one thing all Alaskans swear by to get a good night’s sleep. Darkening curtains (or blackout curtains as most Alaskans call them) aren’t only for bedrooms. Most homes in Alaska have some type of curtains or blinds in the main rooms of the house that are easy to open and close and help filter light depending on the time of day. Blackout curtains are typically used in bedrooms because they are usually made from heavier material or are lined for extra light reduction (also helpful in keeping the bedroom a lower temperature). If you’re exceptionally light-sensitive, you may also want to consider a sleep mask.

Consider using supplements

Living in Alaska can mess with your body’s natural production of hormones such as vitamin D and melatonin. When the sun sets, your body produces melatonin to trigger sleep before bed. The body’s production of melatonin helps keep your circadian rhythm in check.

Unfortunately, Alaska’s near-constant sunlight in the summer interrupts this process and can result in poor sleep, a disrupted sleep cycle, or sleep deprivation. Our bodies need the melatonin production to keep our sleep cycles intact. To counteract this, many Alaskans enlist the help of melatonin to aid in sleep, especially during the transition from winter to summer.

(Consult your physician or a sleep specialist before taking any supplements).

Maintain a normal eating schedule

One thing that easily gets thrown off balance during Alaska summers are eating schedules. Until you’ve adjusted to summer in Alaska, you’ll want to keep your meal schedule as close to normal as you did before arriving in Alaska.

Of course, it’s important to listen to your body’s natural cues to hunger but because of the extensive daylight, it’s not uncommon to spend a day in the Alaska sunshine only to realize you haven’t had dinner yet. A quick glance at the time and you may be surprised to realize it’s nearly 2300! Eating too close to bedtime can disrupt your sleep and can severely impact your health.

If you don’t already, you will soon love summer in Alaska. Taking proper care and setting yourself up with the proper tools and schedule for a good night’s rest will make for more fun on the last frontier.

node.title: Why Bear Spray is Important – Bear Spray 101, Part 1 – AKRDY
node.content:
Bottom Line Up Front (BLUF): Bear spray is effective, relatively cheap, and easy for all family members to use.

            Full disclosure, I’ve never used bear spray against a bear. Unfortunately, if you spend any time in the Alaskan wilderness, you will come across a bear and may need to defend yourself. Bear spray meets this objective and is easy to learn.

What is Bear Spray

Bear Spray is an aerosolized spray derived from capsaicinoids designed to stop a bear attack on humans. Capsaicinoids are popularly found in chili peppers and other plants of the Capsicum species. In layman’s terms, we’re spraying chili pepper in the bear’s face.

            Chili Pepper spray might not sound effective. But when they reduce those peppers to only the ‘heat,’ it causes a violent reaction in the bear. If you’ve eaten a hot pepper, you’ve had a mild version of this reaction. Burning and intense pain in your mouth, watery eyes, and runny nose. Remember, this was when you ate the pepper. Now imagine having those same compounds sprayed into nose and eyes as well.

            The result is debilitating for the bear. In addition to the pain, the capsaicinoids overtake the nostrils and eyes, neutralizing the bears’ ability to smell and see. When combined, you can understand why bear spray stops a 1500 lb bear in its tracks.

Different Bear Encounter Situations

  • Surprise Encounters (High Risk): This is what most people think about when discussing bear attacks and for a good reason. A surprise encounter is when you and the bear meet unexpectantly. These meetings will usually occur in densely wooded areas and narrow or overgrown trails. The problem with these encounters is that all parties will be reacting out of shock and muscle memory. Just in case you’re wondering, the human has a distinct disadvantage. Since the bear is faster, more muscular, and has a lot more practice killing. These are the situations that you want to avoid, great for bear spray. Skip ahead to learn how to use bear spray.  
  • Seen from a Distance (Low Risk): These are the situations that most people come to Alaska to experience. Bear viewing from a distance is incredible and allows you to experience their world from a safe view. Viewing from afar enables the human to ‘introduce’ themselves to the bear, so there are no surprises. These are low-risk situations because there’s time to react, in a level headed manner. You have time to take pictures or move to a safe place if needed. It also allows time to prepare your defense.  
  • Predatory Bears (High Risk): Predatory bears fall outside normal bear behavior for most black and brown bears. These are bears that are initially scared off by human presence but will continually come back. They purposefully hunt humans to kill or consume. There might be multiple reasons they come back, but each reoccurrence is a potential threat to both human and bear. These are high-risk situations because when the bear returns, it’ll require you to either use more bear spray or shot the bear. Eventually, you will either get back to your car, run out of the bear spray, kill the bear, or die. 

Do You Need Bear Spray?

Based on the numbers alone, your odds of getting attacked by a bear are very low. From 1880-2015 bear attacks averaged only 2.6/year in Alaska (Smith et al., 2018). Compared to the number of visitors, hunters, and anglers that venture into bear territory, your odds are good. These bear attack deaths aren’t trivial. The risk of not bringing bear spray is death. In Russia, where half the world’s Brown bears are, the numbers are only slightly higher at four injuries or deaths per year (Kudrenko et al., 2020).

            We’ll cover preparation in the section on using the bear spray, but we know that certain circumstances and time of year are riskier. High-risk months are from Aug-Oct, Brown bears are more prone to attack then black bears. Additionally, hunters have a higher rate of being attacked than groups of two or more.

            If you can plan accordingly, stay in big groups, and stay on well-traveled areas, you probably don’t need to bear spray. Ultimately, your choice. To quote the Hunger Games, “May the odds ever be in your favor.”

Bear Spray vs. A Gun

In Alaska, having a gun in the wilderness is a staple. For some, it’s the bravado of gun ownership that drives their decision. For others, the lethality of the weapon gives it the upper hand. This thought is understandable. A gun is far more accurate, has longer range, and deadlier then bear spray. But in practicality, bringing a gun comes down to training.

            Are you trained to use a gun correctly? Let me give you a scenario. You’ve decided to hike along one of the many trails on the Turnagain arm. It’s a beautiful day, a little cold, but perfect for hiking. You’ve been hiking for about two hours. You round a corner where the trail crosses over one of the many creek crossings. As you make the corner, you ask your hiking partner what they’d like to get for dinner on the way home. The trail is a little overgrown in this section. You look up and see a black bear with cubs in the middle of the trail about 40 feet from you. Momma bear is startled and starts to charge. For a startled bear, closing a 40 ft gap will only take a couple of seconds.

How Comfortable are you with a gun?

Do you feel comfortable enough with a gun to draw, aim, and shoot effectively in this situation? If yes, then great. Most people would not, a better way of saying this is most people are not prepared, and this is where the bear spray comes in. It doesn’t take very long to learn how to use bear spray effectively. Shooting a gun does take time and practice.

Some activities may lead to using a gun more than others. For example, if you’re hunting, then you’re likely to have your gun at the ready. You’ll also be more vigilant of your surroundings and more likely to have practiced shooting the gun. Unfortunately, hunting comes with higher risk of getting attacked. Probably since you’re not making noise, hard to see, and appear a threat.   

Using a gun for defense against bears also makes multiple assumptions. The assumptions are you have the money to purchase a firearm. For a bear gun, it’ll cost about ten times the cost of bear spray, $500-$1000. It also assumes you have the storage for the weapon and a good holster for carrying the gun in the woods. Finally, it assumes you have the time to learn to use it correctly.

The Research

This last assumption is the most critical and is what is supported by research. In a review of 269 bear incidents in Alaska from 1883-2009, Smith et al. (2012) found that “…only those proficient in firearms should rely on them for protection in bear country.” The reason for this is when they reviewed these incidents, “…firearm bearers suffered the same injury rates in close encounters with bears whether they used their firearms or not” (Smith et al., 2012). In case you missed this point, for most people having a gun is about the same as not having one at all. Again, if you can’t reliably draw, aim, and shoot in a couple seconds its better to have bear spray.

The research did find that those using a gun killed the bear roughly 60% of the time, which bear spray will not do.

Here’s some other considerations when carrying a gun:

  • If you miss, are you prepared to shoot the bear who is now on top of you? Do you have a gun that allows appropriate recoil?
  • If the bear chooses your hiking partner, are you ready to hit the bear who is on top of them? Meaning, you won’t also shoot your partner.
  • Lastly, do you have kids? We’ll discuss this in the next section, but they add a whole new twist. What about using a gun near towns, camping spots, busy trails?

Guns are great tools for bear defense in adequately trained hands. Use bear spray if not adequately prepared. Use a firearm as a backup to bear spray if you don’t often shoot, which is my strategy. I use bear spray for any surprise situations but also pack a firearm for predatory bears.

If you’re comfortable with guns and primarily go on solo or small hunting trips having a weapon as your only defense is a smart choice. If you’re like the rest of us who go on a variety of outings with a variety of people, buy some bear spray. 

Kids Using Bear Spray

            Bear spray is excellent for kids in the right situations and training. Bear spray is also dangerous if the child cannot be trusted or not supervised. Don’t leave bear spray in the hands of an idol child or letting them play with bear spray the car. Common sense applies here.

            We give our kids bear spray to carry while hiking or when we go on bike rides. The understanding is that it stays in the holder or belt loop unless needed. We also go over how to use it and when. Bear spray is simple to use.

            Most kids over the age of 6 can probably use bear spray without issue. All that is needed is remove the cap, point at bear, push on lever. Before our trips we discuss a couple important uses. First, the child can use if bear is at charging them. Second, I ensure the child knows how to use the bear spray if the adults are getting mauled. PLEASE SPRAY ME WITH BEAR SPRAY IF A BEAR IS ON TOP OF ME! This is why bear spray is good for kids. It gives them a tool to save my life.

            Proper training applies, but a great resource when needed.

node.title: Bear Spray Specs and Features – Bear Spray 101, Part 2 – AKRDY
node.content:
BLUF: Bear spray specs and features are straightforward. Push-button, spray shoots out. There are three areas to check when buying bear spray: the amount of active ingredient, spray distance, spray pattern.  

            Let’s breakdown all the cool bear spray specs and features for 2020. But like all products don’t get lost in the weeds. Remember, bear spray is about being able to quickly stop a 1500lb bear from eating you so stick to the important features.

Important Bear Spray Features

  • Active Ingredient: The active ingredient in bear spray is a major consideration. Spoiler, all bear sprays on the market have the same active ingredient, the industry standard for bear spray is Capsaicinoid compounds, with a max concentration of 2.0%. Honestly, every major bear spray uses the same active ingredient and most max out the concentration.
  • Shooting Distance: This should make intuitive sense. You want a bear spray that shoots far so that the bear doesn’t end up at your feet. It also gives you more time to get spray into the air as the bear is running towards you. If you spray enough some of it is bound to get on the bear. Bear spray, distance isn’t the only determination here. We also want a spray pattern that fogs, see next.
  • Spray Pattern: This isn’t a backyard game of super soakers. The spray pattern from a can of bear spray should fog up not stream. Again, thinking about a bear running towards you should make this clear. You want to cover as much air with capsaicinoids as possible. If the bear spray only shot out as a stream then we’re back to guns and ensuring we aim accurately. We don’t have time for this. A nice fog ensures that the bear spray covers the entire path in front of the bear and the bear will run into the spray. We want a bear spray that will fog up at the further possible distance.
  • Overall Weight: This is a minor consideration but important for some trips. Some backpackers will want to reduce weight whenever possible. There really are about two types of bear spray sizes; 7.9oz and 9.5oz. The can needs to hold enough propellant to shoot the spray to an effective distance. The larger can might be more efficient since it allows a bit more spray and cuts back the need to bring two cans.
  • How to Carry: Most spray cans will come with a holster of sorts. The most popular is a pouch with a belt loop. This may work for a lot of hikers but just ensure that the product you buy has a holder that works for you. Don’t underestimate the importance of this pouch. Bear spray isn’t going to be effective if you can’t get to it. Don’t stuff bear spray inside your pack, keep it external. UDAP has a nice clip on holster called the griz guard that can clip to multiple locations. Some of the sprays will come with chest holsters as well.

node.title: Top 10 Items to Keep in Your Car for Winter Months - AKRDY
node.content:
Winters in Alaska can be beautiful and brutal, especially if you aren’t prepared. Road condition can change quickly during a storm and you want to make sure that your car is stocked with all the things you will need to survive an emergency. With the right plan in place, you can safely travel during cold weather and handle any situation that may arise. Here are the top 10 items you want to purchase and keep available in your car.

1.   Collapsible Snow Shovel

A collapsible model won’t take up too much room in your trunk and will come in handy whether you or a fellow driver find yourselves caught in the snow. You can use the snow shovel to quickly remove inches of snow from the car’s surface and create space around the car so that you can safely get out of any pinch. 

2.   Sand or Non-Clumping Cat Litter

During the winter, it is all too easy to find yourself spinning your wheel on slick surfaces. Whether you got caught in a sudden snowfall or you have slid off into a snowbank, it can be tough to gain traction. Hitting the accelerator can mean getting stuck further into the snow. Your best bet is to dig out as much snow from around the tires as possible and cover the surface with sand or non-clumping cat litter. Try to get as much as you can close to and under the tire. This will help create traction so that the tire can catch and go to work getting your car back on the road.

3.   Cold Weather Clothing

Maybe you are just heading up to the road to the store, so you just grabbed the nearest jacket and didn’t bother with all the accessories. If something goes wrong, this can leave you exposed to dangerously cold conditions. Be sure to always have a blanket, hand warmers, gloves, warm socks and a hat in your vehicle. If you are planning on a long trip, it is also a good idea to pack a sleeping bag.

4.   Road Flares

If something happens, you want to be able to attract attention and seek out help as soon as possible. Road flares can be used to help illuminate your car and signal your location to other drivers and emergency personnel. Be sure to purchase road flares with the longest burning time available and have several available so that you can ignite a few rounds of flares if needed.

5.   Flashlight

In some locations in Alaska, the winter means weeks without seeing the sun. At the very least, you will be dealing with shorter days and long nights, so be sure to include a durable and waterproof flashlight in your safety kit. Keep an extra set of batteries nearby or opt for a hand crank version so that you never have to worry about running out of power.

6.   Bottled Water and Food

When you are surrounded by snow, it doesn’t seem like you would have to worry about a ready supply of water. However, consuming snow to stay hydrated during an emergency can be a dangerous choice. If your body is already struggling to stay warm, eating snow can drop your internal temperature. Bottled water will help you stay warm and hydrated. Some high calories snacks can also help if you are stranded for a long period of time.

7.   First Aid Kit

No matter what the weather, you should always have a first aid kit in your car. Be sure to purchase a kit that includes: band-aides, antibacterial ointment, antiseptic wipes, medical wrap and adhesive tape. These items will allow you to handle a wide range of medical emergencies and dress any cuts or scrapes until you can get to a professional.

8.   Multi-Purpose Tool

It is a good idea to invest in a multi-purpose tool and keep it handy in your car. Instead of storing a pocket knife, screwdrivers, scissors, wrenches and other tools, you can have a compact solution that can help with practically any situation. There are models that include over twenty different tools including saw blades and hammers. You can choose a combination of tools that best fits your needs and be prepared for emergencies.

9.   Cell Phone Charger

Many of us are guilty of letting our phone’s battery drain. In normal circumstances, this can be an annoying inconvenience, but in an emergency, it can be a real problem. Avoid getting caught with a dead phone by keeping an extra charger in your car. You may even want to go one step further and include a charging pack so that you don’t have to rely on the car’s battery as a source of power.

10. Jumper Cables

Cold weather is hard on your car’s battery. When the temperature drops to 32℉, your battery loses 35% of its power. At 0℉, your battery is operating at just 40% of its normal strength and your engine will need twice as much current to start the engine. That is why it isn’t uncommon to need a boost during the winter months. Avoid getting stuck in the cold by having a set of jumper cables in your trunk.

If you have to jump your car, remember that the positive cable connects to the positive terminal. Both the positive and negative terminal should be clearly marked, but if you are having trouble reading the label, the positive terminal is usually slightly bigger. In addition, the positive jumper cable will be red and the negative cable will be black. Keep these details in mind so that you aren’t left guessing during a stressful situation.

+1: Tow Strap

Last but not least, have a tow strap handy. Find a strap that is rated for the weight of your car. If you're not sure, use 5000lb for most small cars and 10,000lbs for SUVs and Trucks. It's also important that you actually attach it to your tow brackets to ensure it works. Some tow brackets require clips to attach. A tow strap will be helpful for your car and if needed you just might have the tools to help someone else out.

While you can’t prevent accidents, you can do your best to be prepared for the unexpected. Keeping these 10 items in your car will help you survive the winter months and handle a variety of emergency situations. Start putting together your winter car kit now so that you are ready when the weather turns cold.

node.title: Top 10 Items to Always Have When Hiking - AKRDY
node.content:
Whether you are heading out for an easy hike at your local park or you are about to tackle an expert level trail that will have you hiking for most of the day, preparation is key. You want to make sure you have all the Top 10 hiking essentials you need to handle changing weather conditions, respond to an emergency, and survive to be outdoors for extended periods of time. This doesn’t mean that you will have to lug around pounds of bulky equipment. With the right tools and clothing, you can safely enjoy any hike and be prepared for the unexpected. To help you plan for your next hike, here are the 10 items you will always want to have with you.

1.   The Right Footwear

Investing in the right hiking boots can make all the difference in the world. It won’t take long for ill-fitting shoes to start causing blisters and if you get caught in the rain or have to deal with wet trails, you can end up soaked and cold. When looking for the right hiking boot, you will want to take into account fit, water resistance, durability, weight, and warmth.

If you plan on tackling more difficult terrain, you may want the extra protection and support of above ankle boots. However, in most cases, ankle-high boots should do the job. In addition, if you will be dealing with cold temperatures, be sure to get a boot that provides adequate warmth. For warmer hikes, focus on breathable liners and materials that allow for airflow that increases comfort.

Above, all, you want a well-fitting boot. That means a tight heel and a little bit of wiggle room in the toes. This will provide additional room for thick socks and allow for some movement.

2.   A Map and Compass

It is important to bring navigational tools and knowledge to use them. While most people rely on their phones and GPS devices, there is always the chance that technology will fail. You might find yourself out of range of a signal or your battery can die. When that happens, a compass and map will be enough for you to orient yourself and find your way back.

3.   Rain Gear and Extra Clothes

No matter how many times you checked the weather, conditions can change quickly and you can find yourself in the middle of windy, cold, and/or wet weather. Raingear is essential for every trip. Be sure to bring rain gear and extra clothes that take into account the season and how long you expect to be outside. Focus on layering and packing quick-drying items. Also, always include socks, gloves and a warm hat. These clothing items can help protect your extremities and regulate your overall body temperature.

4.   A Fire Starter

Many people make sure that they have a butane lighter on them, but you will want to go the extra mile and bring along waterproof matches or matches stored in a waterproof container. An even better strategy is to purchase a flint or magnesium firestarter. These products come with a striker that can be hit against a bar of flint in order to produce sparks. Bring along a baggie of dryer lint and you will have the perfect ignitable material and a firestarter that will operate in any conditions.

5.   Headlamp

If you find yourself still out on the trail once it gets dark, a headlamp can be an invaluable safety tool. The hands-free design will allow you to keep your balance or manage other items and the power light will illuminate the trail so that you don’t trip over logs, rock, and other hazards in your way. The light can also help you avoid any unwanted wildlife encounters.

6.   First Aid Kit

It should go without saying that a first aid kit should always be a part of any hiking outing. You never know when an injury or illness will occur and even the simplest of medical supplies can make a big difference.

7.   Multi-Tool that Includes a Knife

Number 7 of the Top 10 hiking essentials is a solid multi-tool. While a good knife can get you out of any number of sticky situations, a multi-tool is even more versatile. Look for a product that comes with a knife, small saw blade and pliers. Some models even include a small ax head and silverware. Whether you go for a simpler or more complex model, a multi-tool can help with repairing gear, creating a shelter, and administering first aid.

8.   Sun Protection

Even during the winter months, exposure to too much sun can be dangerous and snow blindness can occur as the rays reflect off the surface of the snow. Throughout the year, you will want to have sunscreen, sunglasses and protective clothing to limit UV rays. Look for a sunscreen with an SPF 30, which can block 97% of UVB rays. 

9.   Temporary Shelter

A temporary shelter can be a lightweight space blanket or ultralight tarp. You want something that is going to keep you warm, safe, and protected from the elements. While a tent is great, you probably don’t want to be carrying around that much weight. Any emergency shelter should be lightweight and portable enough that you always have it on you in case you become injured or stranded. 

10.  Plenty of Water and Purifying Tools

As a general rule, most people need a half-liter of water per hour. Be sure to bring enough supplies based on how long you expect to hike. If the temperatures are high and it is going to be a strenuous hike, you will want to bring extra water. To help survive during emergencies, pack your choice of water purifying tools. Iodine tablets are an inexpensive, effective, and lightweight option, but you will have to wait 20-30 minutes for the water to be purified. For faster results, you can use a water filter, but this approach requires manual pumping and the unit will add weight to your pack.

These Top 10 hiking essentials will help you safely enjoy a hike and handle practically any situation. As you shop around for the best products for your hiking pack, remember to focus on lightweight items that can serve multiple purposes. There are plenty of versatile products on the market that will help you safely enjoy the outdoors.

node.title: Snagging Hook Central - Alaska Fishing 101, Part 5
node.content:
Bottom Line Up Front (BLUF): Snagging is a great way to fill the freezer. Find a cheap source for snagging hooks, you’ll likely lose a few while fishing. Most hooks will be of similar quality.

Alaska offers a very unique fishing opportunity in snagging fish. You don’t have to be a resident to snag fish, just need a fishing license. Snagging fish is only allowed in specific saltwater locations. Generally, this is saltwater near Seward and Prince William Sound. Check the Alaska Fish and Game website for current regulations.

Yes, snagging fish means taking a large treble hook and casting into the water and pulling the hook quickly through the water until you snag into a fish. The hook can snag any part of the fish. It doesn’t have to be the mouth. Snagging isn’t like using lures, the fish won’t bite the snagging hook. Snagging fish is a method of harvesting fish. Although there is some sport to the process, mostly this is about filling your freezer with fish.  

This doesn’t make snagging fish bad, its just a unique way of fishing that is not found in many other places. Snagging fish is a great way to fill the freezer, much like dip netting.  

Types of Snagging Hooks

The most common style of snagging hooks is a weighted style with the weight attached to the main shank of the hook. All snagging hooks have a treble, three, hooks.

Columbia River Tackle makes a weighted treble hook with the weight the extends out of the back of the hook. The theory for this style is that it opens up the hooks for more room to snag the fish. The weight for these hooks is usually the same amount just located behind the hook.

Some of the other manufactures make hooks with the weight in various shapes. We’re not aware of any advantage this offers in snagging fish.

Common Snagging Hook Sizes

10/0 (pronounced ten ought), 8/0, or 6/0 are the most common sizes for snagging hooks. Most fishers use 10/0 or 8/0. You can find snagging hooks as small as 4/0 at places like Walmart or Fred Meyer and as large as 14/0. The practicality of using hooks that are too small or too large may outweigh the perceived benefit.

Generally speaking, hooks of smaller size will have less weight and will be cheaper. Conversely, bigger hooks will be more costly and have a larger weight. The advantage of having more, or less, the weight will come into play when you target specific fish. Also in different waters having a smaller hook may be more advantageous to prevent snagging on non-fish objects.

What is the recommended size of snagging hooks for catching salmon in Alaska?

The recommended size for snagging salmon in Alaska is 10/0. These sizes is commonly found in stores, cheap, and big enough to do the job right. They do cost more money but have the weight to sink fast. They work well in large bodies of water like Seward or Prince William Sound.

Some anglers will prefer 8/0 because they are cheaper and less heavy. This decrease in weight can help delay arm fatigue and may allow kids to participate. Like everything in life each angler will develop their own preference so try a few sizes out and see what works for you.  

Snagging Hook Manufactures

There’s not many large snagging hook manufactures. In our research here’s a list that we found smallest to largest, or local to international:

  • Columbia River Tackle (CRT): CRT is located in Chugiak, AK. A small company that mostly operates from the garage. They make lots of lures and weights, to include both styles of snagging hooks. This includes the custom style and weight behind style.
  • Matzuo America: Matzuo is a part of Big Game America. They are a big company with years of experience making hooks and lures. They offer the classic snagging hook variety.
  • Danielson: Danielson is also another big name brand company that makes many styles of lures and fishing equipment. They make classic weighted snagging hooks.
  • Home Made: Weighted snagging treble hooks are easy to make and you can find them for sale on Facebook or local sales channels.

Places to Buy Snagging Hooks

  • Akrdy.com: Ok, so we’re biased, but check out our online store. We usually will have the cheapest prices and free shipping to JBER. We also carry a wide assortment of sizes and styles.
  • B&J Sporting Goods: This is a local store, located off Northern Lights Blvd in mid-town Anchorage. Great expertise and knowledge of gear, location, and species to target.
  • Fred Meyer / Walmart: I lump these together because they are technically local but they offer a random assortment of hooks at times. For example, you can get some really cheap hooks from Fred Meyer but you need to buy a 10 pack and they only come in sizes 4/0, 5/0, and 6/0. The 6/0 size was sold out at the time of this writing. I’ve heard Walmart is a great place to buy as well.
  • Amazon: As usual, you can find the standard hook sizes from Matzuo and Danielson on Amazon.

How to Snag Fish In Alaska

Fish snagging hooks like other lures. The speed at which they are dragged through the water and the depth of the hook will determine how many fish you catch. In addition, time should be taken to determine where the fish are located in the water to ensure the hook is at the correct depth.

The primary species of fish that anglers target is Sockeye Salmon, commonly called red salmon or ‘reds’. Generally speaking, Red Salmon will be near the top of the water and edges. This will be the same for Coho, aka Silver, salmon. For example, if fishing at McDonalds machine works in Seward, these are smaller streams, and depth without the tide is only a couple of feet. In these conditions, look to target the salmon a couple of feet from the bank. In order to do this, you’ll need to keep the hook lower in the water so that it is in the strike zone near the shore.

For areas of deeper water like the Seward lagoon outflow. You will want to target about 20 feet off shore. In some cases, you can see the schools of fish swimming in front of you. This is deeper water but the salmon will still stay close to the surface. Keeping your retrieval fast will ensure you’re up in the zone.

Snagging Strategies

The speed of retrieval will determine the depth the hook sinks. Slower retrieval will lead to an increased depth. Regardless of how fast you’re able to reel, your hook will have a sinking motion followed by a quick upturn when the rod is whipped back. Pull the rod off to your side to ensure the hook is kept at the optimum depth. This will make the hook travel along a more flat line.

What you want to avoid is the hook being too close to the surface or too far on the bottom. If on the surface the hook will likely come out of the water, turning into missile vs snagging fish. If the hook is too far on the bottom, it will have a higher chance of snagging of debris.

You can prevent either by allowing the hook to fall to the bottom just after you cast, and pausing during retrieval to allow the hook to sink further into the water.

Problems with Snagging

The most obvious is the danger with snagging is the hook itself. Anytime you are casting, retrieving, and pulling a 1-3 oz weighted treble hook through the water you will have problems. These problems are compounded when hundreds of like-minded people are swinging their snagging hooks around as well. For this reason, give anyone snagging a bit more room then you would another angler.

  • Flying Hooks

The other issue is when the hook comes out of the water. Most times when the hook leaves the water force of pulling it through the water transforms the hook to a missile. If you’re pulling overhead the hook will shoot straight to you. Pulling from the side helps your cause but you need to watch for people around you.

If you hit someone with the treble hook it may not hook the person. It may just give them a good blow to the head or chest. This is not a good strategy to make friends fishing. Needless to say, prevention is best. Watch your own hook but also keep a lookout for other chuckleheads who may hit you with theirs.  

The other issue is in the off chance your knot break and the weighted treble hook goes flying. The nature of casting causes a whipping action at the end of your line. This whipping effect stresses the knots you tie. After a couple of hours, if you don’t have good knots, you won’t have a hook. Not a huge deal but this can be dangerous for others.

To prevent injury, tie good knots, wear eye protection, and stay away from others.

  • Snagging on other items then fish

The other problem with snagging is that you’re prone to lose hooks. These hooks are large and sharp. They will hook into anything from rocks, wood, another lost fishing line, or simply piles of algae. Some of this you can pull in and remove from the hook, other items won’t give your hooks back.

Prevent this by simply learning where to cast. If you know where the snags are you need to avoid them. The Seward lagoon outflow is notorious for having lots of snags, especially near the outflow. At high tide is nearly impossible to see any of the snags. At low tide, you can see where they are. When fishing Seward lagoon outflow for the first time start at low tide and work the tide up. I promise, snagging is much more fun when you don’t lose hooks.

The second way to deal with snags is having a setup that allows for easier time breaking off your leader. Use a smaller weight leader attached to your mainline, i.e. 20lb test. This way if you get snagged it’ll break off faster and you can retie and move on quicker. 

  • Knots in your line

The downfall of a faster retrieval is that your main line is more likely to get caught on the tip of your rod. This occurs when after you pull the rod back if you don’t reel as fast as you move the rod forward. Any extra line will get wrapped around the rod tip. This is not a big deal, just annoying. It takes time to unwrap the line. Your rod type will make this worse, in addition to how fast you’re reeling the hook. Medium and light action rod tips will bounce around a lot more making it more likely you’ll tie up your line on the tip.

To prevent the line from getting wrapped try a heavier action rod with less tip flex. Also, pause after you pull back on the rod to reel in the extra slack.  

  • Shoulder Injuries While Snagging Fish

Pulling the hook through the water is taxing on the body. Snagging is not an easy fishing tactic. It requires either the repeated twisting at the waist or pulling from the arms and shoulders. For this reason, its not uncommon to have sore shoulders. Using your waist to pull the hook can take the stress off your shoulders and vice versa. To do this, hold the rod close to the chest and use your waist movement to do the majority of the work. This is important when the fish aren’t running very strong. In those cases, you might go hours without catching fish and for most people, this just adds insult to injury.

Kids and Snagging Fish

Bringing kids to snag fish should take some careful thought. It really depends on the age, maturity, and your desire to snag. Provide direct supervision to kids younger than five. Direct supervision is by someone who is not fishing. This is due to the number of snag hooks flying around. The child's maturity should determine where to bring older children. If the child is prone to wandering aimlessly, like most children of that age range, then it might be best to stay at camp.

Older kids can snag but given the hard work required wouldn’t expect much from them until they are at least 10, if not 12. Just keep an eye on them to ensure others anglers don’t cut in on them. Some adults will try to take advantage of the kid's fishing spot. Fishing should be enjoyable for everyone, including kids. Given the inexperience of kids, they’ll need more room and time to learn. Allow them the space to learn and they will help fill the bag limits. More importantly, everyone will have fun.

node.title: The Great Alaskan Earthquake of 1964
node.content:
The Alaskan earthquake of 1964 is the largest recorded in the United States. This event not only resulted in extensive damage and loss of life, it also reshaped the local landscape, changed the field of earth science and introduced new construction practices.The earthquake marks a major point in Alaskan history and continues to provide valuable lessons for both residents and scientists.

History of the 1964 Earthquake

On March 27, 1964, which also happened to be Good Friday, a magnitude 9.2 earthquake shook Alaska at 5:35 local time. It lasted a full 4.5 minutes. While the epicenter was located in Prince William sound, just 74 miles southeast of Anchorage, the earthquake was powerful enough to register in 47 out of 50 states. In fact, the earthquake was so massive that Seattle’s icon Space Needle, a full 1,200 miles away, was noticeably swaying. There are only two other earthquakes that have registered with a higher magnitude: the 1960 9.5 magnitude quake in Chile and the 9.3 magnitude quake that shook the Indian Ocean off the coast of Sumatra. 

Unfortunately, the initial earthquake was only the beginning. The seismic activity triggered tsunamis and landslides and destroyed entire communities. Residents lost power, telephone lines and were stranded when roads collapsed and railroads were ruined. While the death toll was reported at 131, only 15 of those deaths are attributed to the first tremors. Most people perished during subsequent events.

Landslides and Tsunamis

Since the earthquake struck right at the coast, it didn’t take long for the tsunamis to bring massive waves crashing onto the shore. Just four minutes after the main quake ceased, a tidal wave wiped out a third of the population in the tiny town of Chenga. Kodiak, Seward and Whittier also experienced significant damage due to tsunamis that caused a rise in sea levels of up to 170 feet in certain areas.

The earthquake also caused landslides across the state. In some places, the soil actually began behaving like liquid, which caused a district of Anchorage to drop a full nine feet and carried an entire bluff in Turnagain Heights out into the ocean. With so little time between major events, most residents didn’t have the opportunity to find safety, In the weeks following the earthquake aftershocks continued on a regular basis, some of which registered up to a 6.2 magnitude. 

How Did the Earthquake Reshape Alaska?

Residents who experienced the earthquake describe seeing the earth move in waves, which caused permanent changes to the landscape. For example, some areas near Kodiak were raised by 30 feet. Meanwhile, in Turnagain Arm and surrounding areas, the land dropped 8 feet. In the oil port of Valdez, which sat on a foundation of compacted sand and gravel, the soil turned to liquid, which sent much of the city into the port. At the same time, a tsunami hit the area and oil tanks caught on fire, basically decimating the entire city. Today, the rebuilt city of Valdez sits 6 miles away from its original location.

What Caused the 1964 Earthquake?

In 1964, scientists didn’t have a clear understanding of what caused earthquakes. The theory of tectonic plates was controversial and not widely accepted. Since then, scientists have identified 12 main tectonic plates that make up the lithosphere, or the outer layer of the earth’s surface. These plates are constantly moving. The fastest plate moves about 6 inches every year while the slowest plates move just under 2.5 centimeters annually.  

Where these plates converge, there can be collisions that trigger major events on the earth’s surface. Alaska happens to sit on fault formed by the Pacific and North American Plates. The Pacific Plate happens to be denser, which causes it to slide underneath the North American Plate. The movement of these two plates is responsible for creating over 10,000 quakes every year.

While the earthquake was a devastating event that happened without warning, it led to significant advances in Geology and our understanding of the earth. USGS geologist, George Plafker, played a major role in studying the 1964 earthquake and proving the existence of tectonic plates, which is now widely accepted as fact. He was also able to show that plates didn’t just move vertically, but also horizontally. 

Plafker began by paying close attention to the areas of Alaska that experienced the most significant rise and fall of land. He located a previously unknown fault and concluded that centuries of compression between the Pacific and North American plates had built up pressure that simply could no longer be stopped by the friction of the plates. This energy was released in the form of an earthquake.  

How the Earthquake Changed Construction Practices

In response to the destruction of the 1964 earthquake, Alaska changed many of its building practices. Today, buildings are required to adhere to standards set forth by the International Building Code. All structural elements must be reinforced and capable with withstanding motion. Walls are constructed with reinforced concrete and roofs are kept as light as possible. All plumbing and electrical components are installed in a way that allows for movement. Roads and bridges are also built according to the highest standards, which has allowed the state to weather frequent earthquakes with minimal damage and loss of life.

Part of living in Alaska and enjoying all the natural wonders and wilderness also means dealing with regular earthquakes. There is no way to predict exactly when the next mega quake will hit, which is why preparedness is essential. While the 1964 earthquake was devastating, it also led to important discoveries about tectonic plates and earth science and helped to create new standards for construction that are still helping to protect residents.

node.title: The 2018 Alaskan Earthquake
node.content:
While most people associate earthquakes with California, Alaska is also an earthquake prone state and the site of the 1964 megathrust earthquake that registered a magnitude of 9.2, which is the second largest quake on record. In the decades after this historic earthquake, Alaska continued to experience around tens of thousands quakes per year, but none of them came close to the power and magnitude of the 1964 event until November 30, 2018. 

At 8:23 in the morning, the earthquake struck Alaska. Point Mackenzie, which is 10 miles north of Anchorage, was identified as the epicenter. It registered as a 7.1 magnitude earthquake that occurred 19 miles beneath the earth’s surface. After the initial quake, over 80 aftershocks shook the region throughout the days, some of which measured over 5.0 magnitude. Tsunami warnings were issued immediately, but ultimately, no tsunamis were triggered. The aftershocks continued for months after the earthquake although they continued to weaken in intensity.

Cause of the 2018 Alaskan Earthquake   

Following the massive quake of 1964, which resulted in 139 deaths and extensive damage, scientists made major strides in understanding what causes earthquakes. The 1964 megathrust caused large areas of land to rise in some locations and fall in others. By studying these locations, scientists were able to confirm the existence of tectonic plates. Up to that point, the plates were merely part of a theory that the scientific community had yet to accept as fact.

Alaska happens to sit on the boundary of two of the major plates that make up the lithosphere, or the upper layer of the earth’s crust. The smaller Pacific plate is moving in a northwest direction at a pace of 2.8 inches per year and colliding with the massive North American plate. Since the Pacific plate isn’t big enough to actually move the larger plate, it is actually moving under the North American plate in a process known as subduction. 

Subduction boundaries are responsible for the most powerful earthquakes. Other plates interact in ways that may still cause earthquakes, but they are much less severe. For example, a transform fault occurs when plates move horizontally against each other in a strike-slip motion. In these instances, there is some space for movement. Subduction is a much more violent action that produces record breaking earthquakes. 

Damage Caused by the Earthquake

While 117 people were injured during the quake, there were no fatalities and relatively little damage considering the power of the earthquake. Some homes and businesses experienced damage, but there were no major building or bridge collapses. Beside a few roads where the asphalt cracked and collapsed, the infrastructure remained intact. This was excellent news for emergency crews who were bracing for the worst and preparing to deal with rescue efforts in freezing temperatures and limited daylight.

Local residents had several things working in their favor when the earthquake hit. The depth of the earthquake (29 feet) meant that the shocks didn’t travel very far. If the quake would have occurred closer to the surface, communities would likely have faced more challenges. The time of the quake was also serendipitous. At 8:23, first responders were in the middle of a shift change, which meant that there were more police and firefighters on hand and ready to respond to calls for help.

After the 1964 earthquake, experts agreed that it was just a matter of time before another megathrust hit the area. Officials in Anchorage immediately took action and began implementing new building codes, moving cities further away from the coast and enacting other emergency readiness protocols. The buildings that were able to withstand the 2018 earthquake were built according to Anchorage construction standards. Areas that suffered the heaviest damage were not required to follow the same building plan reviews and inspections.  

Lessons from the 2018 Alaskan Earthquake

The damage from the quake clearly showed that the municipal building codes work and protect people and buildings. That is why experts are pushing for the Alaska Legislature to pass laws that require public buildings to be built according to seismic codes. Businesses who need to update their buildings may be eligible for subsidies to help fund renovations. 

The earthquake also revealed some problems with communication in cities outside Anchorage. In Mat-Su, there was a complete breakdown of communication and no information was posted until 90 minutes after the quake. It also took three days for local officials to hold a press conference with updates and information. This was an obvious failure in leadership.

In addition, it was discovered that most of the damage to buildings was caused by sprinkler systems that broke and caused flooding. As a result, firefighters are recommending that buildings install additional bracing and flexible water lines for sprinklers. This will allow for more freedom of movement and hopefully prevent water damage.

It is clear that implementing new building codes after the 1964 earthquake has been helpful. However, there are still areas for improvement. While Anchorage was able to weather the 2018 Alaskan earthquake quake relatively well, it wasn’t the “big one” and that is what the state needs to be prepared to handle. The assumption is that tsunamis wouldn’t be able to reach Anchorage, but scientists are pushing for more research into this area in order to avoid catastrophe.

Ultimately, earthquakes are a part of living in Alaska and there is no way to predict when the next one will hit. That is why preparation is key. Both individual residents and communities need to take steps to prepare for earthquakes, including the next megathrust, which could set a new record for magnitude.

node.title: How to Prepare for an Earthquake
node.content:
While people commonly associate earthquakes with California, Alaska also experiences frequent and powerful earthquakes. In fact, there are about 1,000 earthquakes per month and about 45 exceed a magnitude 5 each year. Alaska has also been the site of the second strongest earthquake in history, which took place in 1964 was recorded at 9.2 magnitude. The state sits at the intersection of two major tectonic plates, which means that these earthquakes will continue to happen and it is inevitable that another megathrust earthquake will hit the region at some point. Since there is nothing we can do to predict or prevent earthquakes, preparation is key. Follow these tips to prepare for an earthquake.

How to Protect Your Home

Over the years, we have learned a lot about how to construct buildings and homes that are more resistant to earthquakes. If you are building a new home, be sure to work with a contractor who is well-versed in seismic codes and can help incorporate the latest tools and techniques into your home. For older homes, there are retrofitting options that can help to sure up the structural components of your home so that it is better able to withstand strong tremors. While this can require some investment, it can be worth the money in order to improve safety, especially if you live in Alaska.

Protecting Non-Structural Items

There are also some easy to implement best practices that will help to protect non-structural items in your home.

  1. Be sure to securely fasten bookshelves and cabinets to the wall. Use metal brackets that can be screwed into the wall studs to help hold everything in place.
  2. When it comes to storage, be careful about placing heavy items on lower shelves so that they don’t come tumbling down or topple the shelving.
  3. Reinforced ceiling fans and any hanging light fixtures.
  4. Bolt heavy appliances, such as refrigerators and water headers to the floor. 
  5. Avoid hanging pictures or mirrors over beds or seating areas.
  6. Be diligent about repairing any cracks so that they don’t expand with the vibrations from the earthquake.
  7. Store any flammable liquids or chemicals on the bottom shelf of locked cabinets. 
  8. Replace any rigid wiring and piping with more flexible options that will allow them to move without breaking during an earthquake.

Prepare Your Family for an Earthquake

It is important to establish a plan of action and make sure that every member of the family knows where to go and what to do in the event of an earthquake or other emergency. There should be safe places within the home that can offer additional protection during an earthquake. Discuss these often so that everyone automatically seeks shelter in these areas without panicking.   

You should also identify a safe meeting place where everyone can gather once it is safe to move. This will help keep track of everyone and prevent family members from being separated during an emergency. The meeting location should be easily accessible and consider making it on higher ground in case the earthquake triggers tsunamis. 

When an earthquake hits, you should drop, cover and hold on. If there is a desk or table nearby, take cover under this item and stay put until the tremors stop. In situations where you aren’t near any obvious cover, crouch down next to an interior wall.

Create an Emergency Kit

As a general rule, you want to have two weeks of supplies, including food, water and medicine on hand and ready to go in the case of an emergency. In addition to these items, make sure your kit has:

  1. A hand crank or battery powered radio. This may be essential to receiving news and information
  2. Flashlights and extra batteries
  3. Dust masks to help protect your and your family from contaminated air from dirt and debris
  4. A manual can opener so that you can easily access food
  5. A multitool that includes a wrench or pliers in case you need to turn off utility supply lines
  6. Plastic sheeting or a small tent in case you need to shelter in place   
  7. First aid kit
  8. A sleeping bag for each person in the family
  9. Fire extinguisher
  10. Change of clothes, including a pair of sturdy shoes
  11. A cell phone battery charger
  12. Books, games or puzzles. If you end up stranded for a few days, you will be glad to have a little entertainment.

You should store your emergency kit in plastic bins or duffel bags that can keep the items cool and dry during storage. Also make sure that the kit is easily accessible and not packed away at the back of the garage. Based on your climate and your family, you may want to add other items to the kit, but this list should give you a good start with till help you survive until emergency crews can offer additional help. 

In the years following the megathrust earthquake of 1964, Anchorage and surrounding communities made major changes to building codes and began preparing public spaces for future earthquakes. Over the ensuing decades the city and the state have been able to successfully weather thousands of quakes with minimal damage and injuries. However, these successes should not make people complacent when it comes to earthquake preparedness. More powerful earthquakes are on the horizon and it is vital that residents take steps to prepare their homes and create an emergency plan that can easily be put into action when the next big quake hits.

node.title: How to Prevent Moose Attacks
node.content:
Living in Alaska means that you are bound to have some wildlife encounters. With 200,000 Alaskan Moose throughout the state, there is a good chance that you will get close to one of these enormous animals. On average, an adult moose will stand over six feet at the shoulder and weigh well over a 1,000 pounds. While they aren’t usually aggressive, they will attack if they feel threatened and their sheer size makes them a potential danger to humans. That is why it is important to know what to do to prevent a moose attack.

Moose Behavior

For most of the year, the Alaskan moose is a solitary creature. If you encounter more than one, it may be mating season, which is when these animals can turn aggressive. Mating or rutting season tends to peak in lake September and early October. During this period, males may work together to herd females and create a sort of moose harem. While the cows tend to lay in pits, the males will fight for the right to mate. In fact, a moose’s neck will double in size during the rut so that they can more effectively spare with other males. A female will typically only mate with one male, so mature bulls have to ward off younger bulls and in some cases, the fight can result in death. 

During the summer months, moose spend most of their time leisurely looking for food and tend to be slow-moving. They are not territorial animals, so if you come across one in the wild, you should be able to safely observe it from a distance and slowly exit the situation. When startled moose are known to attack humans throughout the year. In addition, mothers can be protective over their calves, so beware if you see a young moose. 

Natural Moose Predators

While moose are enormous animals, they are hunted by natural predators in the wild. A pack of gray wolves can effectively overtake and kill a moose, and brown bears are also known to attack, although these animals will typically look for smaller calves and avoid large bulls. 

Historically, humans have been the deadliest predator for moose although Alaska has established clear restrictions when it comes to hunting these creatures in order to preserve their numbers. For non-residents, the hunting season lasts from September 8-17 and requires a permit. Hunters are only allowed to kill one moose and their antlers have to be at least 50 inches or have over 4 brow tines. Alaskan residents have an extra hunting window from August 24-28 although they are still limited to one mature bull.

What to Do if You Encounter a Moose

There are some basic rules of wildlife etiquette that will help keep both you and moose safe:

  1. Never feed wildlife. Moose have a very specialized diet that is nutrient-rich and low in fiber. Not only is feeding a moose danger for humans, but the design of the digestive system of a moose can not handle something as simple as hay. It can actually kill a moose. In addition, feeding a moose comes with a $110 fine. 
  1. Keep your distance. If you notice that the moose’s behavior changes in any way, then you are too close. You can safely observe these creatures from a distance without creating a stressful situation.
  1. Keep dogs away from moose. Dogs tend to bark at and even run after moose, which can trigger an attack.
  2. Limit observation time. Even if you don’t notice the moose becoming stressed, don’t push your luck. Limit the amount of time you spend observing them.
  1. Be patient. If a moose is blocking the road of your path, be patient. They can be slow moving, but you don’t want to trying to hurry them along can be dangerous.

Moose Attack Body Language

While a moose can be unpredictable, their body language will change if they are feeling threatened. A moose will make eye contact, lower their head, lay back their ears, grunt and stomp when they are about to attack. People tend to think of moose as slow-moving creatures, but they can be extremely quick and flexible when necessary. In fact, they are the only species in the deer family that can kick with both the front and back legs in all directions. That means that you can receive a blow even if you approach it from the side. When a moose raises its hackles it is about to charge. It is also important to keep in mind that all of these cues can happen in a split second. You may not have enough time to observe the moose’s body language and start to retreat, so be careful not to provoke a moose. 

What  to Do if a Moose Charges

Running the is the best thing you can do when a moose charges. If you can, try to put a tree or car between you and the animal as you make your retreat. Typically, once a moose feels that you are a safe distance away, they will stop attacking. If you aren’t able to escape in time, there is a good chance that you will receive a kick from one of their front hooves. If hit, continue to retreat. While it is unusual for a moose to strike repeated blows and engage in a sustained attack, your best line of defense is to get as far away as possible. 

It is important to treat local Alaskan wildlife with respect. Not only will this help protect you from a moose attack, but it will also allow the moose to avoid stressful situations. When you do encounter a moose, keep your distance, and immediately retreat if you do see any signs of aggression. While these animals aren’t inherently aggressive, they will attack if they feel threatened or want to protect their young.

node.title: How to Prevent a Bear Attack
node.content:
Alaska is home to a diverse population of wildlife that includes both brown (or grizzly) bears and black bears. If you live in Alaska, it can be quite common to encounter one of these majestic and intelligent animals. While they are an exciting sight to see, they also present a real danger and it is important that you take steps to prevent a bear attack and know exactly what to do if you find yourself in a sticky situation. Follow this guide to learn more and protect yourself from a bear attack.

Black Bears

Black bears are the most common type of bear and inhabit most of Alaska. While they are called black bears, they can come in different shades of brown, white and black. They tend to have bigger ears, darker colored claws and a brown line with a flatter slope than brown bears. Black bears are also significantly smaller than other species. On average, an adult male will 

reach 180 to 200 pounds.

Black Bear Behavior

Black bears tend to be solitary creatures, except during the mating season or in cases of a mother and her cubs. They have a home range that they roam in order to find food and water, but they aren’t territorial and don’t mind coming across other bears and animals in their space. While there have been 23 deadly black bear attacks from 1900 to 1980, these animals aren’t considered especially aggressive. Typically, attacks are motivated by hunger, especially in areas where bears have become used to eating human food.

Black Bear Body Language

Black bears give plenty of warning signs when they are feeling threatened. They will slap the ground, snort air through their nose and snap their teeth together. If this doesn’t work, they will charge and then quickly veer away in a bluff attack. These bears scare easily and don’t want a confrontation. Any aggressive body language is simply meant to scare you off and avoid having to attack.

How to Survive a Black Bear Attack

First and foremost, always carry bear pepper spray and have it handy so that you can easily spray a charging bear. Also, remember that black bears aren’t very aggressive and usually bluff an attack just to get you to leave. If you stand your ground, make lots of noise and wave your arms around, you can probably prevent an attack. Never run, climb a tree or play dead. This can provoke an attack and black bears are excellent climbers. In the rare case that you are attacked, fight back by punching it in the nose.  

Brown Bears

Unlike black bears, grizzly bears have a muscular hump on their shoulders and shorter, rounder ears. They are also significantly bigger and weigh over a thousand pounds. These bears live throughout Alaska and have a population of over 30,000. 

Brown Bear Behavior

Over the centuries, brown bears evolved and adapted to living in treeless areas. This makes them more aggressive than black bears. They are more likely to stand their ground when they feel threatened. This is especially true when it comes to mothers who are protecting their young. While they aren’t territorial, they will protect food sources. 

Brown Bear Body Language 

When it comes to body language black and brown bears send similar signals. Brown bears will also sway their heads, snap their teeth, snort and lay back their ears. The big difference is that black bears are typically bluffing and will run away if you make enough noise. On the other hand, this type of aggressive behavior from a brown bear should be taken seriously. They don’t bluff and they will act on their warning signals.

How to Survive a Brown Bear Attack

Remember that brown bears behave differently than black bears. They are much more likely to react even at a greater distance. While bear spray is your best bet, there are some other rules of thumb that will help you survive a brown bear attack.

Brown bears are not great climbers, so if you can make it up a tree, this could provide safe shelter. While you want to run from a black bear, this is not the right move with a brown bear. Despite their size, they are incredibly fast and will certainly give chase. If the bear gets close enough and makes contact, play dead. The vast majority of attacks are defensive in nature. Essentially, they are trying to eliminate the threat and not kill you, which is why playing dead can work. Lay on your stomach and cover the back of your head with your hands. The bear may try to roll you over, so stick out your elbows and use them to remain on your stomach. If the bear is able to flip you, keep rolling until you are able to land back on your stomach. 

Try to remain calm and still until the bear stops attacking. Once the bear leaves, continue to play dead for at least 30 minutes before you get up. This will give the bear enough time to get a safe distance away.  

Learn the Difference between Black and Brown Bears

As you can see, the way you should react to an encounter with a bear depends greatly on the type of bear. Black and brown bears have completely different behaviors, which influence how they react to perceived threats and how they defend themselves and their young. It is important to understand the distinguishing features of black and brown bears so that you can quickly identify what you are dealing with and react accordingly. This knowledge can help you avoid confrontations and safely enjoy the Alaskan wilderness.

node.title: Top Ice Cream Destinations In Alaska
node.content:
Alaska offers a host of family-friendly activities and restaurants and what's more family-friendly than ice cream? Here is the master list for the best ice cream joints in Alaska coming from ice cream loving Alaskans.

Wild Scoops |Anchorage, Alaska|

This unique ice cream shop located in downtown and midtown Anchorage is a classic favorite for all resident Alaskans. Holding true to their name, Wild Scoops offers a variety of uncommon flavors such as Sitka Swirl, Fireweed, and even Spruce Tip. Their menu is ever-changing, always adding new and exciting options to their list. When creating flavors they use all-natural ingredients along with their Alaska themed add-ins, including on their menu vegan and dairy-free alternatives. They are always accepting local produce such as rhubarb and berries which they will trade for pints of ice cream, this means the flavors and produce stay local while supporting the community and bringing people closer together. In addition to cake cones, they also hand-make waffle cones on-site that are very delicious and add to the amazing experience. Another one of their specialties is the Baked Alaska which is a homemade waffle cone filled with the ice cream of your choice and topped with toasted marshmallow meringue. Through this pandemic they have remained open, however, they aren’t allowing in-store seating. You can easily order over the phone((907) 444-0714) or on their website and utilize their curbside pick up. At their Midtown location, they are providing take-out if you prefer. The reviews for Wild Scoops are very satisfactory, the staff is friendly and helpful, the service is efficient and careful and the ice cream is a must-have. Overall, Wild Scoops is a highlight of the dessert scene in Anchorage. 

Information: (907) 744-7295, Wild Scoops Website, Reviews for Wild Scoop

Motley Moo |Anchorage, Alaska|

This new and upcoming sweet stop has been receiving solid reviews from Alaskans all over. Popular for its smooth and creamy ice cream it also boasts of one of the best dairy-free ice creams around. With unique flavor names such as Freckle-Faced Mint and Crude Oil, Motley Moo is definitely a crowd-pleaser. All of their produce and dairy are sourced from Havemeister Dairy right here in Alaska keeping it local and fresh year-round. The owner of Motley Moo, Calesta Ayer was born and raised in Alaska along with her husband and son. With this passion for the community, they have set up a charity fund, “Motley Moo Milk Fund”, and donate as much as they can to families and people in need. They strive to connect local businesses with social responsibility through this fund which they allocate 1% of all of their sales towards. They are open for curbside pickup currently but you can find their amazing ice cream in various other eateries around town such as Moose’s Tooth and 49th State Brewing. Or even better, stop by their scoop shop where you can purchase pint\quart sizes of all of your favorites.

Information: (907) 522-1190, Motley Moo Website, Reviews for Motley Moo

Woohoo! Ice Cream |Anchorage, Alaska|

Known for it’s fun and mouth-watering cold treats, Woohoo! Ice Cream also represents Alaska in the 50 Best Ice Cream Parlors in America. They pride themselves on their super-premium ice cream, meaning the fat content is high and the ingredients are of the highest quality. A flourish of organic honey mixed with this ice cream base creates its signature ice cream that is so loved by Alaskans. Some of their more popular flavors include the Maple Butter Pecan, Summer Construction(Rocky Road), and the sweet but spicy Thai Tea flavor. Along with the creamy and magical ice cream they serve, their customer service is also through the roof. Owned by the married couple, Peter and Taian Trujillo-Woo the passion they have for the community and for ice cream simply shine through their smiles and friendly greetings. In response to COVID-19, they have shortened their hours but still are open for takeout or curbside pickup if you’d prefer. 

Information: (907) 351-3087, Woohoo! Website, Reviews for Woohoo!

Little Millers |Wasilla, Alaska|

Soft serve with a twist, seriously. Famous for its flavor burst ice cream cones, Little Millers is a small cafe located in Wasilla. They create the flavor burst by lining the ice cream with a delicious sauce (flavor is optional). You’re left with a colorful and fun treat. It not only has soft serve but also smoothies baked goods and coffee. Even though the pandemic they are still serving takeout as well as opening a drive-thru. 

Information: (907) 376-6129, Little Millers Facebook Page, Reviews for Little Millers

Harbor Street Creamery |Seward, Alaska|

A quick one-stop-shop that has all of your favorite cold treats! Floats, coffees, smoothies, soft serve, and sundaes are just the tip of the ice cream iceberg here. Even with the seemingly endless amount of options the quality still remains top-notch. It’s a perfect place to stop after fishing or on a hot day. The environment is very welcoming as well and the customer service is exemplary.

Information: (907) 224-8818, Harbor Street Creamery Facebook Page, Reviews for Harbor Street Creamery

Flagship Creamery |Homer, Alaska|

Crepes and ice cream are what make this little creamery stand out in Homer, Alaska. They serve the classic flavors with an optional topping of their homemade sauces. As for the crepes you can choose either sweet or salty depending on their daily flavor board. But why choose when you can have both? The Crepe Bomb is an ice cream filled crepe and a popular favorite. 

Information: (907) 299-8624, Flagship Creamery's Facebook Page, Flagship Creamery Reviews

COPPA |Juneau, Alaska|

A must-have if you crave unusual flavors, COPPA is a modern and unique ice cream joint located in Juneau. Black Cod, Blue Cheese, and Spruce Tip have all been past flavors. Along with great ice cream, they also offer salads, sandwiches, and take and bake cinnamon rolls. They boast of great customer service and ambiance.  

Information: (907) 586-3500, COPPA Website, Reviews for COPPA

Hot Licks Ice Cream |Fairbanks, Alaska|

First opening in February of 1986, Hot Licks Ice Cream provides a classic take on ice cream making it a great experience for the whole family. This little stop in Fairbanks offers flavors such as Northern Bluet and Prudhoe some unique flavor names that taste amazing. Be sure to stop by for not only delicious ice cream but a novel experience.

Information: (907) 479-7813, Hot Licks Website, Reviews for Hot Licks

node.title: Photography In Alaska
node.content:
Alaska is full of amazing places and opportunities that allow people to experience the out of the ordinary. What better way to capture Alaska's natural beauty and awe than through photography. I've compiled a list of famous photographers, photography experiences, and some tips on taking photos in Alaska.

Photographers in Alaska

While there a hundreds of talented and knowledgeable photographers in Alaska,

Chris Marler Photography

Chris is a fine art, landscape, and wildlife photographer originally from Boise, Idaho. He took up nature photography as a teenager, and his hobby turned into his career. Chris graduated from the University of Idaho with a degree in computer science, which helped him discover different software and shaped his vision. He retired in 2019 and turned his photography into a full-time career. One of his personal goals is to visit every National Park, and he’s got 32 down with 30 remaining. 

https://www.chrismarlerphotography.com/

Hugh Rose Photography

A professional photographer located in Fairbanks, Alaska, Hugh Rose has a passion for the Arctic. In his own words, “I find the arctic of Alaska, and it’s diverse flora and fauna to be one of the most interesting and scenically beautiful places on earth and thus an inspirational region for photography.” Hugh loves to get off the beaten path and away from the tourists to take his photos. He has a guide service for others like him who like to experience the raw, natural Alaska. 

To purchase his work or learn more about him, you can visit ﻿https://hughrosephotography.com.

Tekalnika Photography

Run by Colorado natives Guy Runco and his wife, Shina duVall, Teklanika Photography provides a beautiful take on nature. The name was inspired by the Teklanika River, the core feeder stream into the Yukon River. A lover of the outdoors, Guy spends hours in nature studying wildlife and capturing breathtaking photos. 

To purchase Guy’s work or learn more about him you can visit, 

https://www.teklanikaphotography.com/index

Ray Bulson Photography

https://www.raybulson.com/alaska-fine-art-photos

Charters are the perfect way to experience
