node.title: 5 Peaks to Summit Near Anchorage
node.content:
There is a reason that people use the term, "mountain top experience." As a hiker, reaching the peak of a mountain is an exhilarating moment that's hard to reproduce anywhere else. The challenge, the views, and the simple knowledge that you've gone as far as you can on a mountain make reaching a peak a worthwhile experience.

In Alaska, the sheer number of peaks surrounding you at any given location can feel overwhelming. It can be hard to know where to start, especially if you are new to hiking. We've narrowed the choice down to five popular hikes, within an hour of Anchorage, that offer beginners a chance to bag their first peak!

Mount Baldy

Difficulty: Moderate (depending on which route up the mountain you decided to take.)

Length: Approximately 3 miles round trip

Elevation gain: 1512 feet

Parking: Free

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/mount-baldy-trail

There is a reason that alltrails.com marks this as "heavily trafficked." It is one of the most popular hikes in the Anchorage area! There are two gates at the end of the Mt Baldy parking lot. Choose the one on the right, as the one on the left is private property.

Early in the hike there are a series of switchbacks that wind through fields which, from the end of June to the middle of July, are covered in wild flowers. As summer gives way to fall, you'll find patches of low-bush blueberries dotting the terrain along the trail.  About midway up the mountain you'll face a decision; head straight up, or continue using switchbacks to the peak. As you might imagine, straight up is faster, but more difficult. Trekking poles and good shoes are warranted if you take this avenue and it can be tough on your little hikers or those carrying children. The second option is the longer, but much less steep trail up the back side of the mountain.  There is a small sign directing hikers to these switchbacks, so be on the lookout!

Once you've reach the top, taken pictures and patted yourself on the back, it's time to head back. Just like your trip up, you have options heading down. Again, straight down will be the fastest, but most arduous. Be prepare for some sliding and slipping. Trekking poles are extremely helpful! You can also take the switchbacks down and, if you're lucky, sometimes you'll see paragliders using a nearby ridge as a starting point for their lazy trip to the valley below.

Mt Gordon Lyons

Difficulty: Moderate

Length: 3.5 miles roundtrip

Elevation Gain: 1400 feet

Parking: $5

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/mt-gordon-lyons

The Arctic Valley is a great place to begin to learn the ins-and-outs of hiking. The choices for length and difficulty are many and whether or not you decided to climb all the way up the mountains on either side, you'll still be able to see some fantastic views.

After parking, head towards the little ski lodge in the middle of the valley. From there you'll spot the valley trail. Follow this trail as it slowly winds over streams, through fields of flowers and up to Rendezvous Point, a saddle between Mt Gordon Lyon and Mt Rendezvous. For Gordon-Lyon, head left. The trail is fairly easy to follow. The climb to the peak is moderately difficult, but not excessively steep. It's more of a, "just-keep-putting-one-foot-in-front-of-another" kind of hike. Trekking poles are helpful. At the top you'll be rewarded with views of Denali herself if it's clear!

Heading down can be accomplished by going back the way you came, or ridge walking back towards the parking lot and hiking down the trail right past the research facility that sits above Arctic Valley. Watch out for signs warning you when you've crossed into Military-owned land however!

Mt Rendezvous

Difficulty: Moderate

Length: 3.5 miles roundtrip

Elevation Gain: 1400 feet

Parking: $5

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/rendezvous-peak-trail

This mountain has the same starting point as Gordon-Lyons, the beautiful Arctic Valley. The most direct route to the top of Rendezvous is to follow the valley trail back to the saddle and then head right, following the clearly marked trail that runs along the edge of the ridge.

The climb up Rendezvous, like Gordon-Lyons, is moderately difficult. Pace yourself and don't feel bad if you need to stop and catch you breath. (We've all been there!) The trail is well maintained and easy to follow. There is a point when you have the option of continuing the trail down into the valley (called Hanging Valley, if you want another hiking suggestion) behind Rendezvous. Instead of that (unless you're looking for a very long hike), do a little scrambling to climb up to the peak of the mountain.

From the top you'll be rewarded with fantastic views of Anchorage, the Turnagain Arm, South Fork and the Chugach Mountains. If hiking in the spring, you have the fun option of "glissading" (sliding) down the snowy slopes on the opposite side of the mountain. The serious winter hikers can even buy pants that are designed for this adventurous method of descending! If it's summer time, you can easily spot and follow the trail down as it runs underneath the ski lifts.

Blueberry Hill

Difficulty: Moderate

Length: 2 miles

Elevation Gain: 1128 feet

Parking: Free

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/explore/trail/us/alaska/blueberry-hill

This is a short and sweet peak. The parking is limited, so sometimes is best to plan on an early start to this particular hike. Late spring into early summer provides the best trail conditions, along with the chance to view some gorgeous Alaskan wildflowers. Too early in the season and you'll encounter a lot of very slippery mud as you climb.

Beginning in a birch forest, the trail switchbacks up to the saddle where hikers have the option of heading right or left. For this hike you'll want to head left. That is, head left after you've enjoyed the views of the winding Eagle River, wild lupine, fireweed and (if hiking during the fall) finding handfuls of lowbush blueberries to snack on.

The trail is easy to see from the saddle and simple to follow it up to the peak. There are sections where the trail requires some scrambling, but it's minimal. The views from the top showcase Eagle River and the surrounding mountain ranges (including Baldy, if you've hiked that already!) Once satisfied with all the pictures you've taken and after having patted yourself on the back for having bagged another peak, you simply head back down the same way you came up.

Flattop Mountain

Difficulty: Moderate (most difficult at the very end)

Length: 3.3 miles roundtrip

Elevation Gain: 1430 feet

Parking: $5

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/flattop-mountain

Another very popular hiking destination is Flattop Mountain. There are a few ways to scale this mountain, but we'll detail the most direct route, up the front.

The hike begins by climbing up a hill named Blueberry Loop - and, as you might imagine, in the fall people frequently leave the trail in order to hunt for nearby  blueberries. Once you reach the back of he loop you'll run smack into the base of Flattop mountain.

A clearly marked trail starts the increasingly steep trek up the face of the mountain. Parts of the climb are punctuated by "steps" (if you can call them that after erosion and earthquakes have caused them to lean pretty precariously!) The last push comes after reaching a small saddle and then following the trail up and through a short, steep scramble over boulders! Little hikers might find it challenging, and parents will need to decide if it's doable. But with patience and assistance, many kids have made it up to the flagpole for a celebratory picture!

Keep an eye out for paragliders on clear days as you head back down the mountain (though, maybe not while scrambling down the boulders. : ) Once you reach the junction of Flattop and Blueberry loop, you can continue the loop around the hill and wind you way back to the parking lot.

node.title: 5 Stoller-Friendly Hikes Near Anchorage
node.content:
For Alaska's littlest hikers (whether in strollers or backpacks) there are a number of trails that families can enjoy together without worrying about elevation gains and difficult terrain. If you have visitors who are unable to complete uphill hiking, these make excellent options that provide exceptional Alaskan views. Here are five easy hikes for families to enjoy together that are within an hour and a half of Anchorage!

Eagle River Nature Center

Elevation Gain: Flat

Length: Various; shortest route is .8 miles round trip.

Parking: 5$

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/parks/us/alaska/eagle-river-nature-center

This is easily one of the most beloved family destination in the Anchorage area, and for good reason. The views are spectacular, the options for length of hike are numerous, and most of the trails are flat and stroller accessible (with all-terrain strollers fairing the best.) 

The most common of these is the Rodak Nature Loop which is an easy walk from the parking lot down to the viewing deck and back. However you can easily venture father back along the old Iditarod trail for a few miles. All the trails are well marked and easy to follow. Wildflowers grow in abundance and there are more than a few fun places for children to climb and explore right off the main trail. During the spring and summer you do need to check at the center for reports regarding bear activity. Keep the bear spray close and the bear bells (or children) loud : )

Eklutna Lake Bike Trail

Elevation Gain:  Flat

Length: In and out for as long as you'd like.

Parking: 5$

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/eklutna-lakeside-trail

Whether you want to hang out by the lake skipping rocks, ride bikes or take strollers along the paved trail, or hike up to a mountain overlook, there are lots of things to keep families busy at Eklutna Lake. During the summer there are even kayak rentals available for those looking for some aquatic adventure!

For families with littles, the paved bike trail that runs along the edge of the lake is perfect for an lovely walk in the summer or fall. You can easily leave the trail at multiple points to go down to the lake and explore. Go as far as you'd like before turning around and heading pack to the parking lot. The full trail is 12 miles one way with some elevation gain starting around mile 10. Whichever direction you are heading, the views can't be beat.

Reflection Lake

Elevation Gain: Flat

Length: 1.1 Mile roundtrip

Parking: Free

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/reflection-lake-trail

This is another favorite spot for families. At just over a mile, the trail is the perfect length for little legs. Strollers are able to make the loop fairly easily, allowing for a few bumps due to roots and uneven packed earth in places. As it's name implies, the lake is a beautiful, calm body of water. You can spend a lot of time taking pictures of the mountains and their reflected image as you walk. In the wintertime, this lake freezes and the hike can be cut in half if you are willing to walk across the frozen expanse! Be sure to pack bug spray as the mosquitoes love the sitting water of the marsh behind the lake. And while mosquitoes aren't very welcome, the lookout by the marsh provides visitors with opportunities to see beaver, muskrats and moose!

Byron Glacier Trail

Elevation Gain: 100 ft

Length: 2 miles

Parking: Free

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/byron-glacier-trail

Many people use this trail to hike all the way to the back of the valley and up to the glacier. However, for those not looking for such a strenuous adventure, the first part of the trail is relatively flat and easily navigated. All-terrain strollers can make the trip over the packed earth trail, though there are sections where it's a little bumpy and rocky. Along the way are places to stop and creek stomp in the (chilly) glacial melt and in late summer the path is lined with salmon berries and raspberries!

Once you reach the end of the designated trail the valley opens up and you can explore the rocky terrain and enjoy the beautiful views. Be wary of standing under or climbing on top of snow caves however! These can quickly become unstable, leading to collapse. Stay safe by enjoying the views from a slight distance.  Nonetheless, snow itself is lots of fun and there are plenty of snow patches around the valley, even into early July.  Snowball fights in July…now who wouldn't love that! Bear spray is warranted as is bug spray, especially during late spring.

Powerline Pass

Elevation Gain: Flat (for first few miles)

Length: 1-2 miles for strollers

Parking: 5$

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/powerline-pass-trail

Powerline pass provides families with an easily accessible trail near Anchorage with creeks to play in, flowers to view and various options for length of hike. As it's name suggests, the trail runs underneath a powerline which is positioned  in the valley between two mountain ranges.  If you've hiked Flattop Mountain, you've most likely looked down at this family trail from above. Parking is shared with those hiking either Blueberry Knoll or Flattop.  The trail itself is a mix of gravel, boardwalk and packed earth. All-terrain strollers are easy to use for the first mile or so. Again, always pack bear spray and keep your eyes out for other wild life! It can also be windy, so a jacket would be worth having on hand.

node.title: 5 Moderately Difficult Hikes Near Anchorage
node.content:
Not everyone feels the need to reach a mountain peak during every hike, sometimes a fantastic view is plenty. Thankfully, Alaska is full of moderately challenging hikes that will leaving you breathless (because of the beauty, not the hike!) Here are five beautiful hikes that are within an hour and a half of Anchorage.


Gold Cord Lake Trail

Difficulty: Easy-Moderate

Length: 1.5 miles roundtrip

Elevation Gain: 482 feet

Parking: 5$

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/gold-cord-lake

This trail is directly across from the Independence Mine area of Hatcher Pass. You can see the trail head where it starts, direct across the road from the entrance to the upper parking lot. The hike winds across the flat valley floor before snaking up the side of the mountain to a gorgeous glacier lake. The trail runs right along the side of the mountain for a short period of time, so tiny hands might need to be held for a little bit. But the cold mountain water is a welcome relief after this short, steep hike and the views of the Hatcher Pass area can't be beat - like in the photo above. Sometimes some clouds will blow through, but don't worry, they race away as fast as they arrive! This is a fabulous hike for beginning hikers and visiting family and friends.

Portage Pass Trail

Difficulty: Moderate

Length: 4.2 miles

Elevation Gain: 1433 feet

Parking: free

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/portage-pass

This is a beautiful trail to hike at various times of the year. Springtime hiking requires crampons for your shoes as you hike through some snowy parts of the trail, summer hiking gives you gorgeous views of wildflowers covering the mountainside and late August brings an abundance of berries to the bushes along the trail. And no matter which season you choose, the view of Portage Glacier from one direction and of Whittier and the Prince William Sound in the other direction never disappoints.

You can choose to either hike to just the top of the Portage Pass and then back down to your parked car, or you can hike up the pass and then down to the edge of Portage lake before heading back up and over. Trekking polls are helpful, but not necessary.

West Butte Trail

Difficulty: Easy-Moderate

Length: 2.3 miles roundtrip

Elevation Gain: 721 feet

Parking: 5$

Website: https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/w-butte-trail

If you live in the Anchorage area, a trip up "The Butte" is almost a rite of passage for any hiker. This short hike is very well maintained and is great for families with children (as long as they are able to manage stairs and railings on their own.) The views of the valley, Knik Glacier, Knik River and Pioneer Peak are amazing. Don't feel bad if you decided to sit and enjoy the views for a while before heading back down. (Though, if you've forgotten your bug repellent, your stay might be shorter as this hike is on the buggier side : ) This is another hike that is excellent for visiting friends and family.

Turnagain Arm Trail

Difficulty: Easy

Length: Varies, up to 4.1 miles roundtrip

Elevation Gain: 741 feet

Parking: 5$

Website:  https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/alaska/turnagain-arm-trail

This trails runs along the Turnagain arm and is easily accessible from the Seward Highway. It offers beautiful views of the inlet, mountains and highway without a strenuous hike to gain them. You can stay on the trail as long as you'd like before heading back to your car. This is another great trail for family and friends because it gives you a taste of the gorgeous Alaskan vistas without steepness or challenging trail conditions. The trail is especially beautiful in the fall when the birch trees are a vibrant yellow!

One note: This trail is known for it's wildlife encounters. Normally you'll  see dale sheep, marmots, and bald eagles. But sometimes, you might run across evidence of bears…meaning it's vital to come prepared with bear spray and bear bells. Stay in a large group and make lots of noise!

April Bowl Trail

Difficulty: Easy-Moderate

Length: 2.2 miles round trip (or less, if you stop at the lake)

Elevation Gain: 856 feet

Parking: free

Website: https://www.alaska.org/detail/hatch-peak-april-bowl-trail

This is another trail in the Hatcher Pass area. Finding the trailhead for this hike was more difficult than I imagined. If you park in the lot for Summit Lake, the trail begins directly behind you on the steep hill leading up to the April Bowl. In the summer the trail may be heavily trafficked, so finding it might be as easy as looking for where other people are headed! The trail is a steep set of switchbacks until you reach the lake. You have the option to stop here and enjoy the amazing views or you can continue up along the ridge that surrounds the lake. At the very top of the ridge is Hatch Peak - so if you feel like it, you can easily cross another mountain top off your list! Trekking poles are helpful, but not necessary for most hikers.

node.title: 5 Berry Picking Spots near Anchorage
node.content:
With berry season upon us, it's a good idea to have a few places that you can depend on to have a good supplies of berries! Before heading out, take a little time to read up on the different types of berries and some general information about them. This site provides a good summary.

Foraging is like an unofficial sport here in the last frontier, and there are people who will methodically pick for hours, patiently filling buckets with nature's bounty. But this means that sometimes the place that you were hoping to clear is already empty due to the hard work of another ambitious person. So here are five different places that have ample amount of berries…hopefully enough to go around.

Mile High Saddle, Eagle River

Type of berry: Lowbush blueberry, crow berries

Parking: free

Mile High is a great place to hunt for blue berries. Because it takes a rather steep hike up through the woods to reach it, many berry pickers decide not to hunt there. Which means that it's perfect for the more adventurous foragers. Because of it's elevation, the berries might be a week behind those growing at lower altitudes. By early August they should be ready though! You can start hunting right off the trail leading into the saddle and just go where ever the berries take you.

Winner Creek Trail, Girdwood

Type of berry: High bush blueberry

Parking: free

Starting at the trailhead located behind the Alyeska Tram, follow the Winner Creek path for a few miles until you find yourself at an old mining bridge. This bridge, which spans the turbulent creek below, is large and well used by hikers. Parents will need to do a quick risk assessment regarding the safety of going across, but with older children a firm handhold  and a slow pace is usually all that is warranted when crossing.

On the other side of the creek is a clearing that is covered with bushes. Blueberry bushes, to be precise. With a little exploring, you can often find a whole bush that has been untouched by other foragers. Be careful walking in the forest however. The ground looks firm but can often be just a mossy covering over fallen branches. Walk carefully, stay within eye-sight of other pickers and have bear bells on and jingling. Humans aren't the only ones who love these berries! However, the Winner Creek area is full of berry producing bushes…so there is a good chance that any bears in the area have found a place far away from people.

Girdwood has a very popular blueberry festival most years, which is when you can expect lots of people to descend upon the hills and forests around the town. My advice is to go berry-picking a few days before the festival, just to beat the crowds : )

Arctic Valley, Eagle River

Type of berry: Low-bush blueberry, low-bush cranberry, crow berry

Parking: 5 dollars

This is a very popular place for berry pickers, with good reason. Starting at the beginning of August, most of the slopes leading down to the valley have large patches of berries scattered across them. A good rule of thumb, when looking for a place to hike towards, is to take a moment and look at where other people are hunkered down. While you don't want to go right on top of them, chances are good that there are more berries in that vicinity. If you ever go hiking in Arctic Valley during the very end of July and beginning of August, keep your eyes out and remember where you saw the most people gathered.

You'll find the low-bush cranberries closest to the creek that runs through the valley.  These extremely tart little gems are easily frozen and make great additions to fruit crumbles, pies and thanksgiving day stuffing. I know this from experience : )

Hatcher Pass, Palmer

Type of berry: low-bush blueberry

Parking: free (on pull outs along the road.)

Due to the higher elevation, these berries are usually ripe in mid-end of August. If you reach the Hatcher pass summit, instead of turning around and heading back, continue heading west on Fishhook -Willow rd, past summit lake and on down the other side of the pass. There are numerous pull-outs along this road that you can park at. Like Arctic Valley, the best way to find a place to pick is to look for other people and head in that direction. Though you can expect to find blue-berries pretty much anywhere along the slopes on either side of the road, its just easier to be a copycat until you get a feel for the area. Be forewarned however, once you start, it's hard to stop! The scenery is gorgeous and  the berries are nearly unending. But once you've filled your bucket, head back up the way that you came and head home to look up recipes for your haul!

Portage Pass Trail, Whittier

Type of berry: Salmon berries

This is definitely a hit-or-miss berry excursion. But if your timing is right (around the middle of July), you can find some amazingly delicious salmonberries.  The instructions are pretty simple, just head up the Portage Pass trail and keep your eyes glued to the bushes on either side of the trail. If you are lucky, they'll be full of these beautiful, juicy gems. My advice would be to plan a hike up the pass anyway, and just keep your fingers crossed that you'll be there right when the berries begin to ripen and before anyone else has discovered them : )

If you head to Whittier to fish for salmon, there is a good chance you'll also be near to some berry picking spots. Just keep your eyes open! Maybe you'll head home with two parts of you dinner taken care of!

Happy hunting!

node.title: 5 Family-Friendly Activities in Alaska
node.content:
Whether you're just visiting or moving here permanently Alaska has so many great options for families with children of all ages. Here are some of the top family-friendly activities you and your loved ones can do while in Alaska.

Anchorage Museum

Anchorage Museum is a great activity for a rainy (or more commonly in Alaska, snowy) day. It has so much to offer for all ages. One of its permanent exhibitions, Art of the North, showcases the beauty of Alaska through different artist’s portrayal. It features many indigenous arts from the villages and native people, such as sculptures, woven fabrics, and photography which provide insight into the heritage of Alaska. Along with this, you can also experience some classical paintings of some of the most prestigious landmarks. For younger children, they also have an interactive area in which children are given the opportunity to explore and learn about Alaska’s weather, cool scientific phenomenons, and even some wildlife. In addition to these, they also host traveling exhibitions that rotate every few months, providing new learning experiences all year round. 

For more information, you can visit, https://www.anchoragemuseum.org/ or call 907-929-9200

Eagle River Nature Center

Looking for a scenic, easy hike for the entire family? Well, look no further than Eagle River Nature Center. From a stroller accessible trail to amazing outlooks and overviews, its the perfect family outing. Before you start on the trail you can visit the lodge, which is a great place to learn a little about the wildlife in that area, through touching polar bear fur or reading cool facts about animals. Outside of the lodge, there is an outdoor eating area, a perfect place to enjoy a packed lunch after the hike. The trail is full of plaques and signs teaching about the wildlife and vegetation in the area. All in all, a trip to the Eagle River Nature Center never disappoints and is a must-see in Alaska. 

For more information, you can visit https://www.ernc.org/ or call 907-694-2108

Wildlife Conservation Center

A unique Alaskan experience for all ages! Wanting to see some Alaskan animals but haven't the chance yet? Well, the Wildlife Conservation Center is a great place to see moose, bears, musk ox, and many more, up close and in their natural habitat. The trip offers not only an unforgettable wildlife encounter but also a learning experience about all of the creatures of Alaska, where they live and how they survive. It is located past Girdwood so it's a bit of a drive from Anchorage but it's one you won't regret.

For more information, you can visit https://www.alaskawildlife.org/ or call (907) 783-0058

Alaska Railroad

With a main line that stretches from Fairbanks to Seward (470 miles), The Alaska Railroad is a perfect way to see all of the beautiful scenery Alaska has to offer via a comfortable and accessible transport. Aside from carrying large freight and hosting events, the railroad also has arranged day trips. The most popular ride, “Coastal Classic Train” will take you along the Turnagain Arm, displaying an amazing view of the bay. It will arrive in Seward late morning, leaving you till 6 pm to explore all that the city has to offer. While the fare is a bit pricey it promises to be a rewarding experience with lasting memories. 


For more information, you can visit https://www.alaskarailroad.com/ or call (907) 265-2300

Alaska Zoo

The Alaska Zoo is a nonprofit working to promote the conservation of the arctic and its wildlife. It hosts over 100 different types of animals across 25 acres. While some are native Alaskan wildlife, they also have exotic animals from all around the world. Since it is a nonprofit the zoo does not receive any state or city funding and relies solely on the profit it brings in to care for the animals. This epidemic has affected the Alaska Zoo greatly so a visit here would not only be a fun family outing but help towards a greater cause. All indoor exhibits are currently closed however you can still visit the gift shop (with a mask on of course).

For more information, you can visit https://www.alaskazoo.org/ or call (907) 346-2133

node.title: Top 5 Alaskan Clothing Brands
node.content:
Moving to Alaska but don’t know what to expect? Well here are the top 5 clothing brands in Alaska that will have you looking like a local.

Xtra Tuf

The weather in Alaska is pretty unpredictable, but you can be prepared for anything with a solid pair of XTRA TUFs. These water-proof boots allow you to do almost anything without having to worry about the muck or mud! Some boots even have cute and unique designs so you can be stylish and weatherproof. All in all, every Alaskan could use a pair of XTRA TUFs.

Popular Item: All-Purpose, Water-proof Boots

Cost: $$-$$$

Reviews:

“I purchased my Xtratuf boots for a small ship cruise in Alaska. I used them several times for small skiff rides and for wading in the water during shore walks. They fit incredibly well and kept my feet warm and dry. All the crew on the ship also wore Xtratuf boots, so I know they have to be good. Looking forward to using them again.” Debra B.

“These boots crush anything in their path, all while keeping the feet dry and comfortable! These boots will be in it for the long haul, and always something I can rely on. The fit is spot on and the look is something I always get compliments on” - Megan O.

For more information or to purchase their boots, you can visit https://www.xtratuf.com/

Ak Starfish Co

Alaska owned and made, AK Starfish Co. is a fun, fashionable way to support a local business. Most known for their stylish hoodies, zip-up jackets, and hats, these clothes are a perfect way to show off your Alaskan pride. The founder, Marci Nelson is a 3rd generation Alaskan who has spent her entire life exploring Alaska’s natural beauty. In fact, her first-ever design came from a photograph of a starfish in Sadie Cove she took. It's a great way to show off your style while supporting a local business.   

Popular Item: Hoodies and Hats

Cost: $$

Reviews:

“Amazing service and quality of the clothing! I love shopping here and knowing I’m supporting local Alaskans.” - Paisley P.


“Marci Nelson creates a wonderful atmosphere for all of her Ak Starfish locations! The hoodies are so soft and durable, not to mention they don't shrink!! Her boutique line is very unique and like no other boutique you will find in Alaska. They also carry tons of Alaskan designed jewelry, stickers, food, cookbooks, and greeting cards!”

For more information or to purchase their clothing, you can visit https://www.akstarfish.com/

Alaska Chicks

Vintage with a twist, ‘Alaska Chicks’ hoodies are a staple here in Alaska. Their clothes are warm and comfortable perfect for the chilly Alaskan winters. And they don't just sell hoodies but gloves, beanies, and leggings, all of which have great reviews from customers. So if you're looking for a gift for your grandma, mom, or daughter that will be used and loved, Alaska Chicks is the place to go.

Popular Item: Hoodies

Cost: $$

Reviews:

“This is my all-time favorite hoodie. Love the style the fabric, and the length. I have two, and ordered one for my daughter who was trying to steal one of mine!” - Donna B.

“I am in love with this hoodie. This is my second one and I've gotten so many compliments, it’s crazy! I love the fabric and how well it washes up and holds its shape. Perfect fitting and just the correct length for wearing with everything from jeans to leggings!” - Brandy B.

For more information or to their purchase their clothing, you can visit https://alaskachicks.com/

Carhartt

Whether you’re fishing, hiking, camping or just enjoying nature you’ll need durable clothing to get you through all of it. Carhartt, most known for their tough, weather-proof outerwear is the perfect option for the entire family when exploring the great Alaskan outdoors.

Popular Item: Overalls, Men’s Coats

Cost: $$-$$$

Reviews:

“First thing that comes to mind when I hear this brand is "DURABILITY.” -Rodrigo T.

“Great, long-lasting, well designed, and functional clothing.” -Anja F.

For more information or to purchase their clothing, you can visit https://www.carhartt.com/

Copper River Fleece

This Alaskan clothing company prides themselves on their unique clothing that showcases the native culture here in Alaska. They're based in Cordova, a small village, and love to use the nature surrounding them in their designs. Tested and approved by hunters, fishermen, and just Alaskans themselves Copper River Fleece has outstanding reviews for durability and longevity. They sell jackets, coats, hats, and all sorts of wearable, fun designs for all ages. Plus, everything is made and designed in the USA!

Popular Item: Lined Jackets

Cost: $$$

Reviews: 

“Copper River Fleece jackets are beautiful, stylish, lightweight (but warm), wind-resistant, well made, and they fit well.  They are quality.  I bought my first jacket a couple of years ago and now have four of them.” - Bonnie T.

“We have purchased jackets for the kids for multiple years. Such an amazing product!” -Mike P.


For more information or to purchase their clothing, you can visit https://www.copperriverfleece.com/
